front.head: THE GOOD-NATUR'D MAN: A COMEDY.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN. FIRST PRINTED IN M,DCC,LXVIII.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: WHEN I undertook to write a comedy, I confess I was strongly prepossessed in favour of the poets of the last age, and strove to imitate them. The term, genteel comedy, was then unknown amongst us, and little more was desired by an audience, than nature and humour, in whatever walks of life they were most conspicuous. The author of the following scenes never imagined that more would be expected of him, and therefore to delineate character has been his principal aim. Those who know any thing of composition, are sensible, that in pursuing humour, it will sometimes lead us into the recesses of the mean; I was even tempted to look for it in the master of a spunging-house: but in deference to the public taste, grown of late, perhaps, too delicate; the scene of the bailiffs was retrenched in the representation. In deference also to the judgment of a few friends, who think in a particular way, the scene is here restored. The author submits it to the reader in his closet; and hopes that too much refinement will not banish humour and character from ours, as it has already done from the French theatre. Indeed the French comedy is now become so very elevated and sentimental, that it has not only banished humour and Moliere from the stage, but it has banished all spectators too.

Upon the whole, the author returns his thanks to the public for the favourable reception which the Good-Natur'd Man has met with: and to Mr. Colman in particular, for his kindness to it. It may not also be improper to assure any, who shall hereafter write for the theatre, that merit, or supposed merit, will ever be a sufficient passport to his protection.

lg.l: PREST by the load of life, the weary mind
Surveys the general toil of human kind;
With cool submission joins the lab'ring train,
And social sorrow, loses half its pain:
Our anxious bard, without complaint, may share
This bustling season's epidemic care.
Like Caesar's pilot, dignify'd by fate,
Tost in one common storm with all the great;
Distrest alike, the statesman and the wit,
When one a borough courts, and one the pit.
The busy candidates for power and fame,
Have hopes, and fears, and wishes, just the same;
Disabled both to combat, or to fly,
Must hear all taunts, and hear without reply.
Uncheck'd on both, loud rabbles vent their rage,
As mongrels bay the lion in a cage.
Th' offended burgess hoards his angry tale,
For that blest year when all that vote may rail;
Their schemes of spite the poet's foes dismiss,
Till that glad night, when all that hate may hiss.
This day the powder'd curls and golden coat,
Says swelling Crispin, begg'd a cobler's vote.
This night, our wit, the pert apprentice cries,
Lies at my feet, I hiss him, and he dies.
The great, 'tis true, can charm th' electing tribe;
The bard may supplicate, but cannot bribe.
Yet judg'd by those, whose voices ne'er were sold,
He feels no want of ill-persuading gold;
But confident of praise, if praise be due,
Trusts without fear, to merit, and to you.

div3.head: SCENE, an apartment in YOUNG HONEYWOOD'S house.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: GOOD Jarvis, make no apologies for this honest bluntness. Fidelity, like yours, is the best excuse for every freedom.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: I can't help being blunt, and being very angry too, when I hear you talk of disinheriting so good, so worthy a young gentleman as your nephew, my master. All the world loves him.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Say rather, that he loves all the world; that is his fault.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: I'm sure there is no part of it more dear to him than you are, tho' he has not seen you since he was a child.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: What signifies his affection to me; or how can I be proud of a place in a heart where every sharper and coxcomb find an easy entrance?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: I grant you that he's rather too good-natur'd; that he's too much every man's man; that he laughs this minute with one, and cries the next with another; but whose instructions may he thank for all this?

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Not mine, sure? My letters to him during my employment in Italy, taught him only that philosophy which might prevent, not defend his errors.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Faith, begging your honour's pardon, I'm sorry they taught him any philosophy at all; it has only serv'd to spoil him. This same philosophy is a good horse in the stable, but an errant jade on a journey. For my own part, whenever I hear him mention the name on't, I'm always sure he's going to play the fool.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Don't let us ascribe his faults to his philosophy, I entreat you. No, Jarvis, his good nature arises rather from his fears of offending the importunate, than his desire of making the deserving happy.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: What it rises from, I don't know. But, to be sure, every body has it, that asks it.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Ay, or that does not ask it. I have been now for some time a concealed spectator of his follies, and find them as boundless as his dissipation.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: And yet, faith, he has some fine name or other for them all. He calls his extravagance, generosity; and his trusting every body, universal benevolence. It was but last week he went security for a fellow whose face he scarce knew, and that he called an act of exalted mu‚Äîmu‚Äîmunificence; ay, that was the name he gave it.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: And upon that I proceed, as my last effort, tho' with very little hopes to reclaim him. That very fellow has just absconded, and I have taken up the security. Now, my intention is to involve him in fictitious distress, before he has plunged himself into real calamity. To arrest him for that very debt, to clap an officer upon him, and then let him see which of his friends will come to his relief.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Well, if I could but any way see him thoroughly vexed, every groan of his would be music to me; yet faith, I believe it impossible. I have tried to fret him myself every morning these three years; but, instead of being angry, he sits as calmly to hear me scold, as he does to his hair-dresser.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p:
We must try him once more, however, and I'll go this instant to put my scheme into execution; and I don't despair of succeeding, as, by your means, I can have frequent opportunities of being about him, without being known. What a pity it is, Jarvis, that any man's good will to others should produce so much neglect of himself, as to require correction. Yet, we must touch his weaknesses with a delicate
hand. There are some faults so nearly allied to excellence, that we can scarce weed out the vice without eradicating the virtue. [Exit.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, sir William Honeywood. It is not without reason that the world allows thee to be the best of men. But here comes his hopeful nephew; the strange, good-natur'd, foolish, open-hearted‚ÄîAnd yet, all his faults are such that one loves him still the better for them.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, Jarvis, what messages from my friends this morning?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: You have no friends.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well; from my acquaintance then?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: (Pulling out bills) A few of our usual cards of compliment, that's all. This bill from your taylor; this from your mercer; and this from the little broker in Crooked-lane. He says he has been at a great deal of trouble to get back the money you borrowed.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: That I don't know; but I'm sure we were at a great deal of trouble in getting him to lend it.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: He has lost all patience.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Then he has lost a very good thing.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: There's that ten guineas you were sending to the poor gentleman and his children in the Fleet. I believe that would stop his mouth, for a while at least.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ay, Jarvis, but what will fill their mouths in the mean time? Must I be cruel because he happens to be importunate; and, to relieve his avarice, leave them to insupportable distress?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! sir, the question now is how to relieve yourself. Yourself‚ÄîHav'nt I reason to be out of my senses, when I see things going at sixes and sevens?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Whatever reason you may have for being out of your senses, I hope you'll allow that I'm not quite unreasonable for continuing in mine.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: You're the only man alive in your present situation that could do so‚ÄîEvery thing upon the waste. There's miss Richland and her fine fortune gone already, and upon the point of being given to your rival.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I'm no man's rival.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Your uncle in Italy preparing to disinherit you; your own fortune almost spent; and nothing but pressing creditors, false friends, and a pack of drunken servants that your kindness has made unfit for any other family.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Then they have the more occasion for being in mine.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Soh! What will you have done with him that I caught stealing your plate in the pantry? In the fact; I caught him in the fact.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: In the fact! If so, I really think that we should pay him his wages, and turn him off.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: He shall be turn'd off at Tyburn, the dog; we'll hang him, if it be only to frighten the rest of the family.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: No, Jarvis: it's enough that we have lost what he has stolen, let us not add to it the loss of a fellow creature!

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Very fine; well, here was the footman just now, to complain of the butler; he says he does most work, and ought to have most wages.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: That's but just; tho' perhaps here comes the butler to complain of the footman.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Ay, its the way with them all, from the scullion to the privy-counsellor. If they have a bad master, they keep quarrelling with him: if they have a good-master, they keep quarrelling with one another.

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Sir, I'll not stay in the family with Jonathan; you must part with him, or part with me, that's the exex-exposition of the matter, sir.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Full and explicit enough. But what's his fault, good Philip?

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Sir, he's given to drinking, sir, and I shall have my morals corrupted, by keeping such company.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ha! ha! He has such a diverting way‚Äî

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: O quite amusing.

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: I find my wines a-going, sir; and liquors don't go without mouths, sir; I hate a drunkard, sir.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, well, Philip, I'll hear you upon that another time, so go to bed now.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: To bed! Let him go to the devil.

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Begging your honour's pardon, and begging your pardon, master Jarvis, I'll not go to bed, nor to the devil neither. I have enough to do to mind my cellar. I forgot, your honour, Mr. Croaker is below. I came on purpose to tell you.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Why didn't you shew him up, blockhead?

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Shew him up, sir! With all my heart, sir. Up or down, all's one to me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p:
Ay, we have one or other of that family in this house from morning till night. He comes on the old affair I suppose. The match between his son,
that's just returned from Paris, and miss Richland, the young lady he's guardian to.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Perhaps so. Mr. Croaker, knowing my friendship for the young lady, has got it into his head that I can persuade her to what I please.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Ah! If you lov'd yourself but half as well as she loves you, we should soon see a marriage that would set all things to rights again.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Love me! Sure, Jarvis, you dream. No, no; her intimacy with me never amounted to more than friendship‚Äîmere friendship. That she is the most lovely woman that ever warm'd the human heart with desire, I own. But never let me harbour a thought of making her unhappy, by a connection with one so unworthy her merits as I am. No, Jarvis, it shall be my study to serve her, even in spite of my wishes; and to secure her happiness, tho' it destroys my own.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Was ever the like! I want patience.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Besides, Jarvis, tho' I could obtain miss Richland's consent, do you think I could succeed with her guardian, or Mrs. Croaker his wife; who, tho' both very fine in their way, are yet a little opposite in their dispositions you know.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Opposite enough, heaven knows; the very reverse of each other; she all laugh and no joke; he always complaining, and never sorrowful; a fretful poor soul that has a new distress for every hour in the four and twenty‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Hush, hush, he's coming up, he'll hear you.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: One whose voice is a passing bell‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, well, go, do.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: A raven that bodes nothing but mischief; a coffin and cross bones; a bundle of rue; a sprig of deadly night shade; a‚Äî (Honeywood stopping his mouth, at last pushes him off.) [Exit Jarvis.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I must own my old monitor is not entirely wrong. There is something in my friend Croaker's conversation that quite depresses me. His very mirth is an antidote to all gaiety, and his appearance has a stronger effect on my spirits than an undertaker's shop.‚ÄîMr. Croaker, this is such a satisfaction‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: A pleasant morning to Mr. Honeywood, and many of them. How is this! You look most shockingly to day, my dear friend. I hope this weather does not affect your spirits. To be sure, if this weather continues‚ÄîI say nothing‚ÄîBut God send we be all better this day three months.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I heartily concur in the wish, tho' I own not in your apprehensions.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
May be not! Indeed what signifies what weather we have in a country going to ruin like ours? Taxes
rising and trade falling. Money flying out of the kingdom and Jesuits swarming into it. I know at this time no less than an hundred and twenty-seven Jesuits between Charing-cross and Temple-bar.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: The Jesuits will scarce pervert you or me I should hope.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: May be not. Indeed what signifies whom they pervert in a country that has scarce any religion to lose? I'm only afraid for our wives and daughters.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I have no apprehensions for the ladies I assure you.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: May be not. Indeed what signifies whether they be perverted or no? The women in my time were good for something. I have seen a lady drest from top to toe in her own manufactures formerly. But now a-days the devil a thing of their own manufactures about them, except their faces.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: But, however these faults may be practised abroad, you don't find them at home, either with Mrs. Croaker, Olivia or miss Richland.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: The best of them will never be canoniz'd for a saint when she's dead. By the bye, my dear friend, I don't find this match between miss Richland and my son much relish'd, either by one side or t'other.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I thought otherwise.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Ah, Mr. Honeywood, a little of your fine serious advice to the young lady might go far: I know
she has a very exalted opinion of your understanding.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: But would not that be usurping an authority that more properly belongs to yourself?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: My dear friend you know but little of my authority at home. People think, indeed, because they see me come out in a morning thus, with a pleasant face, and to make my friends merry, that all's well within. But I have cares that would break an heart of stone. My wife has so encroach'd upon every one of my privileges, that I'm now no more than a mere lodger in my own house.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: But a little spirit exerted on your side might perhaps restore your authority.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: No, tho' I had the spirit of a lion! I do rouze sometimes. But what then! Always haggling and haggling. A man is tired of getting the better before his wife is tired of losing the victory.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: It's a melancholy consideration indeed, that our chief comforts often produce our greatest anxieties, and that an encrease of our possessions is but an inlet to new disquietudes.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Ah, my dear friend, these were the very words of poor Dick Doleful to me not a week before he made away with himself. Indeed, Mr. Honeywood, I nener see you but you put me in mind of poor‚ÄîDick. Ah there was merit neglected for you! and so true a
friend; we lov'd each other for thirty years, and yet he never asked me to lend him a single farthing.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Pray what could induce him to commit so rash an action at last?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I don't know, some people were malicious enough to say it was keeping company with me; because we us'd to meet now and then and open our hearts to each other. To be sure I lov'd to hear him talk, and he lov'd to hear me talk; poor dear Dick. He us'd to say that Croaker rhim'd to joker; and so we us'd to laugh‚ÄîPoor Dick. (Going to cry.)

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: His fate affects me.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ay, he grew sick of this miserable life, where we do nothing but eat and grow hungry, dress and undress, get up and lie down; while reason, that should watch like a nurse by our side, falls as fast asleep as we do.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: To say truth, if we compare that part of life which is to come, by that which we have past, the prospect is hideous.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Life at the greatest and best is but a froward child, that must be humour'd and coax'd a little till it falls asleep, and then all the care is over.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Very true, sir, nothing can exceed the vanity of our existence, but the folly of our pursuits. We wept when we came into the world, and every day tells us why.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ah, my dear friend, it is a perfect satisfaction to be miserable with you. My son Leontine shan't lose the benefit of such fine conversation. I'll just step home for him. I am willing to shew him so much seriousness in one scarce older than himself‚ÄîAnd what if I bring my last letter to the Gazetteer on the encrease and progress of earthquakes? It will amuse us I promise you. I there prove how the late earthquake is coming round to pay us another visit from London to Lisbon, from Lisbon to the Canary Islands, from the Canary Islands to Palmyra, from Palmyra to Constantinople, and so from Constantinople back to London again. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Poor Croaker! His situation deserves the utmost pity. I shall scarce recover my spirits these three days. Sure to live upon such terms is worse than death itself. And yet, when I consider my own situation, a broken fortune, an hopeless passion, friends in distress; the wish but not the power to serve them‚Äî (pausing and sighing.)

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: More company below, sir: Mrs. Croaker and miss Richland; shall I shew them up? But they're shewing up themselves. [Exit.

div3.stage: Enter MRS. CROAKER and MISS RICHLAND.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: You're always in such spirits.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: We have just come, my dear Honeywood, from the auction. There was the old deaf dowager, as usual, bidding like a fury against herself. And then so curious in antiques! herself the most genuine piece of antiquity in the whole collection.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Excuse me, ladies, if some uneasiness from friendship makes me unfit to share in this good humour: I know you'll pardon me.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: I vow he seems as melancholy as if he had taken a dose of my husband this morning. Well, if Richland here can pardon you, I must.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: You would seem to insinuate, madam, that I have particular reasons for being dispos'd to refuse it.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Whatever I insinuate, my dear, don't be so ready to wish an explanation.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I own I should be sorry, Mr. Honeywood's long friendship and mine should be misunderstood.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: There's no answering for others, madam. But I hope you'll never find me presuming to offer more than the most delicate friendship may readily allow.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: And I shall be prouder of such a tribute from you than the most passionate professions from others.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: My own sentiments, madam: friendship is a disinterested commerce between equals; love, an abject intercourse between tyrants and slaves.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: And, without a compliment, I know none more disinterested or more capable of friendship than Mr. Honeywood.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: And, indeed, I know nobody that has more friends, at least among the ladies. Miss Fruzz, miss Odbody, and miss Winterbottom praise him in all companies. As for miss Biddy Bundle, she's his professed admirer.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Indeed! an admirer! I did not know, sir, you were such a favourite there. But is she seriously so handsome? Is she the mighty thing talked of?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: The town, madam, seldom begins to praise a lady's beauty, till she's beginning to lose it. (Smiling.)

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: But she's resolved never to lose it, it seems. For, as her natural face decays, her skill improves in making the artificial one. Well, nothing diverts me more than one of those fine, old, dressy things, who thinks to conceal her age, by every where exposing her person; sticking herself up in the front of a side-box; trailing through a minuet at Almack's; and then, in the public gardens, looking for all the world like one of the painted ruins of the place.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Every age has its admirers, ladies. While you, perhaps, are trading among the warmer climates of youth; there ought to be some to carry on an useful commerce in the frozen latitudes beyond fifty.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p:
But, then, the mortifications they must suffer, before they can be fitted out for traffic. I have seen
one of them fret an whole morning at her hair-dresser, when all the fault was her face.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: And yet, I'll engage, has carried that face at last to a very good market. This good-natur'd town, madam, has husbands, like spectacles, to fit every age, from fifteen to fourscore.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, you're a dear good-natur'd creature. But you know you're engaged with us this morning upon a strolling party. I want to shew Olivia the town, and the things; I believe I shall have business for you for the whole day.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I am sorry, madam, I have an appointment with Mr. Croaker, which it is impossible to put off.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: What! with my husband! Then I'm resolved to take no refusal. Nay, I protest you must. You know I never laugh so much as with you.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Why, if I must, I must. I'll swear you have put me into such spirits. Well, do you find jest, and I'll find laugh, I promise you. We'll wait for the chariot in the next room. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: There they go, thoughtless and happy. My dearest Olivia, what would I give to see you capable of sharing in their amusements, and as chearful as they are.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: How, my Leontine, how can I be chearful, when I have so many terrors to oppress me? The fear of being detected by this family, and the apprehensions of a censuring world, when I must be detected‚Äî

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: The world! my love, what can it say? At worst it can only say that, being compelled by a mercenary guardian to embrace a life you disliked, you formed a resolution of flying with the man of your choice; that you confided in his honour, and took refuge in my father's house; the only one where your's could remain without censure.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: But consider, Leontine, your disobedience and my indiscretion: your being sent to France to bring home a sister; and, instead of a sister, bringing home‚Äî

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: One dearer than a thousand sisters. One that I am convinc'd will be equally dear, to the rest of the family, when she comes to be known.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: And that, I fear, will shortly be.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Impossible, 'till we ourselves think proper to make the discovery. My sister, you know, has been with her aunt, at Lyons, since she was a child, and you find every creature in the family takes you for her.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: But may'nt she write, may'nt her aunt write?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Her aunt scarce ever writes, and all my sister's letters are directed to me.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: But won't your refusing miss Richland, for whom you know the old gentleman intends you, create a suspicion?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: There, there's my master-stroke. I have resolved not to refuse her; nay, an hour hence I have consented to go with my father, to make her an offer of my heart and fortune.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Your heart and fortune!

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Don't be alarm'd, my dearest. Can Olivia think so meanly of my honour, or my love, as to suppose I could ever hope for happiness from any but her? No, my Olivia, neither the force, nor, permit me to add, the delicacy of my passion, leave any room to suspect me. I only offer miss Richland an heart, I am convinc'd she will refuse; as I am confident, that, without knowing it, her affections are fixed upon Mr. Honeywood.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Mr. Honeywood! You'll excuse my apprehensions; but when your merits come to be put in the balance‚Äî

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: You view them with too much partiality. However, by making this offer, I shew a seeming compliance with my father's command; and perhaps, upon her refusal, I may have his consent to chuse for myself.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p:
Well, I submit. And yet, my Leontine, I own, I shall envy her, even your pretended addresses. I
consider every look, every expression of your esteem, as due only to me. This is folly perhaps: I allow it; but it is natural to suppose, that merit which has made an impression on one's own heart, may be powerful over that of another.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Don't, my life's treasure, don't let us make imaginary evils, when you know we have so many real ones to encounter. At worst, you know, if miss Richland should consent, or my father refuse his pardon, it can but end in a trip to Scotland; and‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Where have you been, boy? I have been seeking you. My friend Honeywood here, has been saying such comfortable things. Ah! he's an example indeed. Where is he? I left him here.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Sir, I believe you may see him, and hear him too in the next room: he's preparing to go out with the ladies.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Good gracious, can I believe my eyes or my ears! I'm struck dumb with his vivacity, and stunn'd with the loudness of his laugh. Was there ever such a transformation! (A laugh behind the scenes, Croaker mimics it.) Ha! ha! ha! there it goes: a plague take their balderdash; yet I could expect nothing less, when my precious wife was of the party. On my conscience, I believe, she could spread an horselaugh thro' the pews of a tabernacle.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Since you find so many objections to a wife, sir, how can you be so earnest in recommending one to me?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I have told you, and tell you again, boy, that miss Richland's fortune must not go out of the family; one may find comfort in the money, whatever one does in the wife.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: But, sir, tho', in obedience to your desire, I am ready to marry her; it may be possible, she has no inclination to me.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I'll tell you once for all how it stands. A good part of miss Richland's large fortune consists in a claim upon government, which my good friend, Mr. Lofty, assures me the treasury will allow. One half of this she is to forfeit, by her father's will, in case she refuses to marry you. So, if she rejects you, we seize half her fortune; if she accepts you, we seize the whole, and a fine girl into the bargain.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: But, sir, if you will but listen to reason‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Come, then, produce your reasons. I tell you I'm fix'd, determined, so now produce your reasons. When I'm determined, I always listen to reason, because it can then do no harm.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: You have alleged that a mutual choice was the first requisite in matrimonial happiness.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Well, and you have both of you a mutual choice. She has her choice‚Äîto marry you, or lose half her
fortune; and you have your choice‚Äîto marry her, or pack out of doors without any fortune at all.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: An only son, sir, might expect more indulgence.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: An only father, sir, might expect more obedience; besides, has not your sister here, that never disobliged me in her life, as good a right as you? He's a sad dog, Livy, my dear, and would take all from you. But he shan't, I tell you he shan't, for you shall have your share.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Dear sir, I wish you'd be convinced that I can never be happy in any addition to my fortune, which is taken from his.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, well, it's a good child, so say no more; but come with me, and we shall see something that will give us a great deal of pleasure, I promise you; old Ruggins, the curry-comb-maker, lying in state; I'm told he makes a very handsome corpse, and becomes his coffin prodigiously. He was an intimate friend of mine, and these are friendly things we ought to do for each other. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE, CROAKER'S house.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: OLIVIA not his sister? Olivia not Leontine's sister? You amaze me!

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: No more his sister than I am; I had it all from his own servant; I can get any thing from that quarter.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: But how? Tell me again, Garnet.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Why, madam, as I told you before, instead of going to Lyons, to bring home his sister, who has been there with her aunt these ten years; he never went further than Paris; there he saw and fell in love with this young lady, by the bye, of a prodigious family.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: And brought her home to my guardian, as his daughter?

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Yes, and his daughter she will be. If he don't consent to their marriage, they talk of trying what a Scotch parson can do.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Well, I own they have deceived me‚ÄîAnd so demurely as Olivia carried it too!‚ÄîWould you believe it, Garnet, I told her all my secrets; and yet the sly cheat concealed all this from me?

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: And, upon my word, madam, I don't much blame her; she was loath to trust one with her secrets, that was so very bad at keeping her own.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: But, to add to their deceit, the young gentleman, it seems, pretends to make me serious proposals. My guardian and he are to be here presently, to open the affair in form. You know I am to lose half my fortune if I refuse him.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Yet, what can you do? For being, as you are, in love with Mr. Honeywood, madam‚Äî

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: How! idiot; what do you mean? In love with Mr. Honeywood! Is this to provoke me?

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: That is, madam, in friendship with him; I meant nothing more than friendship, as I hope to be married; nothing more.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Well, no more of this! As to my guardian, and his son, they shall find me prepared to receive them; I'm resolved to accept their proposal with seeming pleasure, to mortify them by compliance, and so throw the refusal at last upon them.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Delicious! and that will secure your whole fortune to yourself. Well, who could have thought so innocent a face could cover so much cuteness!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Why, girl, I only oppose my prudence to their cunning, and practise a lesson they have taught me against themselves.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Then you're likely not long to want employment, for here they come, and in close conference.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Excuse me, sir, if I seem to hesitate upon the point of putting to the lady so important a question.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Lord! good sir, moderate your fears; you're so plaguy shy, that one would think you had changed sexes. I tell you we must have the half or the whole. Come, let me see with what spirit you begin? Well, why don't you? Eh! What? Well then‚ÄîI must, it seems‚ÄîMiss Richland, my dear, I believe you guess at our business; an affair which my son here comes to open, that nearly concerns your happiness.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir, I should be ungrateful not to be pleased with any thing that comes recommended by you.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: How, boy, could you desire a finer opening? Why don't you begin, I say? (To Leont.)

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: 'Tis true, madam, my father, madam, has some intentions‚Äîhem‚Äîof explaining an affair‚Äîwhich‚Äîhimself‚Äîcan best explain, madam.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Yes, my dear; it comes intirely from my son; it's all a request of his own, madam. And I will permit him to make the best of it.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: The whole affair is only this, madam; my father has a proposal to make, which he insists none but himself shall deliver.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: My mind misgives me, the fellow will never be brought on. (Aside.) In short, madam, you see before you one that loves you; one whose whole happiness is all in you.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I never had any doubts of your regard, sir; and I hope you can have none of my duty.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: That's not the thing, my little sweeting; my love! No, no, another guess lover than I; there he stands, madam, his very looks declare the force of his passion‚ÄîCall up a look, you dog‚ÄîBut then, had you seen him, as I have, weeping, speaking soliloquies and blank verse, sometimes melancholy, and sometimes absent‚Äî

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I fear, sir, he's absent now; or such a declaration would have come most properly from himself.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Himself! madam, he would die before he could make such a confession; and if he had not a channel for his passion thro' me, it would ere now have drowned his understanding.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I must grant, sir, there are attractions in modest diffidence above the force of words. A silent address is the genuine eloquence of sincerity.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Madam, he has forgot to speak any other language; silence is become his mother tongue.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p:
And it must be confessed, sir, it speaks very powerfully in his favour. And yet I shall be thought too
forward in making such a confession; shan't I, Mr. Leontine?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Confusion! my reserve will undo me. But, if modesty attracts her, impudence may disgust her. I'll try. (Aside.) Don't imagine from my silence, madam, that I want a due sense of the honour and happiness intended me. My father, madam, tells me, your humble servant is not totally indifferent to you. He admires you; I adore you; and when we come together, upon my soul I believe we shall be the happiest couple in all St. James's.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: If I could flatter myself, you thought as you speak, sir‚Äî

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Doubt my sincerity, madam? By your dear self I swear. Ask the brave, if they desire glory? ask cowards, if they covet safety‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, well, no more questions about it.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Ask the sick, if they long for health? ask misers, if they love money? ask‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ask a fool, if he can talk nonsense! What's come over the boy? What signifies asking, when there's not a soul to give you an answer? If you would ask to the purpose, ask this lady's consent to make you happy.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Why indeed, sir, his uncommon ardour almost compels me, forces me to comply. And yet I'm afraid he'll despise a conquest gained with too much ease: won't you, Mr. Leontine?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Confusion! (Aside.) O, by no means, madam, by no means. And yet, madam, you talked of force. There is nothing I would avoid so much as compulsion in a thing of this kind. No, madam, I will still be generous, and leave you at liberty to refuse.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: But I tell you, sir, the lady is not at liberty. It's a match. You see she says nothing. Silence gives consent.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: But, sir, she talked of force. Consider, sir, the cruelty of constraining her inclinations.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: But I say there's no cruelty. Don't you know, blockhead, that girls have always a roundabout way of saying yes before company? So get you both gone together into the next room, and hang him that interrupts the tender explanation. Get you gone, I say; I'll not hear a word.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: But, sir, I must beg leave to insist‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Get off, you puppy, or I'll beg leave to insist upon knocking you down. Stupid whelp. But I don't wonder, the boy takes entirely after his mother. [Exeunt miss Rich. and Leont.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Mr. Croaker, I bring you something, my dear, that I believe will make you smile.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I'll hold you a guinea of that, my dear.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: A letter; and, as I knew the hand, I ventured to open it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And how can you expect your breaking open my letters should give me pleasure?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Poo, it's from your sister at Lyons, and contains good news: read it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: What a Frenchified cover is here! That sister of mine has some good qualities, but I could never teach her to fold a letter.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Fold a fiddlestick. Read what it contains.

sp.speaker: CROAKER,
sp.p: 'DEAR NICK,

'AN English gentleman, of large fortune, has for some time made private, tho' honourable proposals to your daughter Olivia. They love each other tenderly, and I find she has consented, without letting any of the family know, to crown his addresses. As such good offers don't come every day, your own good sense, his large fortune, and family considerations, will induce you to forgive her.
'Yours ever, RACHEL CROAKER.'

My daughter, Olivia, privately contracted to a man of large fortune! This is good news indeed. My heart never foretold me of this. And yet, how slily the little baggage has carried it since she came home. Not a word on't to the old ones for the world. Yet, I thought, I saw something she wanted to conceal.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, if they have concealed their amour, they shan't conceal their wedding; that shall be public, I'm resolved.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I tell thee, woman, the wedding is the most foolish part of the ceremony. I can never get this woman to think of the more serious part of the nuptial engagement.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: What, would you have me think of their funeral? But come, tell me, my dear, don't you owe more to me than you care to confess? Would you have ever been known to Mr. Lofty, who has undertaken miss Richland's claim at the treasury, but for me? Who was it first made him an acquaintance at lady Shabbaroon's rout? Who got him to promise us his interest? Is not he a back-stairs favourite, one that can do what he pleases with those that do what they please? Isn't he an acquaintance that all your groaning and lamentations could never have got us?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: He is a man of importance, I grant you. And yet, what amazes me is, that while he is giving away places to all the world, he can't get one for himself.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: That perhaps may be owing to his nicety. Great men are not easily satisfied.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p:
An expresse from monsieur Lofty. He vil be vait upon your honour's instrammant. He be only giving
four five instruction, read two three memorial, call upon von ambassadeur. He vil be vid you in one tree minutes.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: You see now, my dear. What an extensive department! Well, friend, let your master know, that we are extremely honoured by this honour. Was there any thing ever in a higher style of breeding! All messages among the great are now done by express.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: To be sure, no man does little things with more solemnity, or claims more respect than he. But he's in the right on't. In our bad world, respect is given, where respect is claim'd.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Never mind the world, my dear; you were never in a pleasanter place in your life. Let us now think of receiving him with proper respect (a loud rapping at the door) and there he is by the thundering rap.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ay, verily, there he is; as close upon the heels of his own express, as an indorsement upon the back of a bill. Well, I'll leave you to receive him, whilst I go to chide my little Olivia for intending to steal a marriage without mine or her aunt's consent. I must seem to be angry, or she too may begin to despise my authority. [Exit.

div3.stage: Enter LOFTY, speaking to his servant.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p:
And if the Venetian ambassador, or that teazing creature the marquis, should call, I'm not at home. Dam'me, I'll be pack-horse to none of them. My dear madam, I have just snatched a moment‚ÄîAnd if
the expresses to his grace be ready, let them be sent off; they're of importance. Madam, I ask a thousand pardons.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Sir, this honour‚Äî

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: And Dubardieu! if the person calls about the commission, let him know that it is made out. As for lord Cumbercourt's stale request, it can keep cold: you understand me. Madam, I ask ten thousand pardons.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Sir, this honour‚Äî

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: And, Dubardieu! if the man comes from the Cornish borough, you must do him; you must do him, I say. Madam, I ask ten thousand pardons. And if the Russian‚Äîambassador calls: but he will scarce call today, I believe. And now, madam, I have just got time to express my happiness in having the honour of being permitted to profess myself your most obedient humble servant.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Sir, the happiness and honour are all mine; and yet, I'm only robbing the public while I detain you.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Sink the public, madam, when the fair are to be attended. Ah, could all my hours be so charmingly devoted! Sincerely, don't you pity us poor creatures in affairs? Thus it is eternally; solicited for places here, teized for pensions there, and courted every where. I know you pity me. Yes, I see you do.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Excuse me, sir. Toils of empires pleasures are, as Waller says.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Waller, Waller; is he of the house?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: The modern poet of that name, sir.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Oh, a modern! We men of business despise the moderns; and as for the ancients, we have no time to read them. Poetry is a pretty thing enough for our wives and daughters; but not for us. Why now, here I stand that know nothing of books. I say, madam, I know nothing of books; and yet, I believe, upon a land carriage fishery, a stamp act, or a jag-hire, I can talk my two hours without feeling the want of them.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: The world is no stranger to Mr. Lofty's eminence in every capacity.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: I vow to gad, madam, you make me blush. I'm nothing, nothing, nothing in the world; a mere obscure gentleman. To be sure, indeed, one or two of the present ministers are pleased to represent me as a formidable man. I know they are pleased to be-spatter me at all their little dirty levees. Yet, upon my foul, I wonder what they see in me to treat me so! Measures, not men, have always been my mark; and I vow, by all that's honourable, my resentment has never done the men, as mere men, any manner of harm‚Äîthat is as mere men.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: What importance, and yet what modesty!

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p:
Oh, if you talk of modesty, madam! there I own, I'm accessible to praise: modesty is my foible: it was so, the duke of Brentford used to say of me. I love
Jack Lofty, he used to say: no man has a finer knowledge of things; quite a man of information; and when he speaks upon his legs, by the Lord he's prodigious, he scouts them; and yet all men have their faults; too much modesty is his, says his grace.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: And yet, I dare say, you don't want assurance when you come to solicit for your friends.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: O, there indeed I'm in bronze. Apropos, I have just been mentioning miss Richland's case to a certain personage; we must name no names. When I ask, I am not to be put off, madam. No, no, I take my friend by the button. A sine girl, sir; great justice in her case. A friend of mine. Borough interest. Business must be done, Mr. Secretary. I say, Mr. Secretary, her business must be done, sir. That's my way, madam.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Bless me! you said all this to the secretary of state, did you?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: I did not say the secretary, did I? Well, curse it, since you have found me out I will not deny it. It was to the secretary.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: This was going to the fountain head at once, not applying to the understrappers, as Mr. Honeywood would have had us.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Honeywood! he! he! He was, indeed, a fine solicitor. I suppose you have heard what has just happened to him?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Poor dear man; no accident, I hope.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Undone, madam, that's all. His creditors have taken him into custody. A prisoner in his own house.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: A prisoner in his own house! How! At this very time! I'm quite unhappy for him.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Why so am I. The man, to be sure, was immensely good-natur'd. But then I could never find that he had any thing in him.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: His manner, to be sure, was excessive harmless; some, indeed, thought it a little dull. For my part, I always concealed my opinion.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: It can't be concealed, madam; the man was dull, dull as the last new comedy! A poor impracticable creature! I tried once or twice to know if he was fit for business; but he had scarce talents to be groomporter to an orange barrow.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: How differently does miss Richland think of him! For, I believe, with all his faults, she loves him.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p:
Loves him! Does she? You should cure her of that by all means. Let me see; what if she were sent to him this instant, in his present doleful situation? My life for it, that works her cure. Distress is a perfect antidote to love. Suppose we join her in the next room? Miss Richland is a fine girl, has a fine fortune, and must not be thrown away. Upon my honour, madam, I have a regard for miss Richland;
and, rather than she should be thrown away, I should think it no indignity to marry her myself. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: And yet, trust me, Olivia, I had every reason to expect miss Richland's refusal, as I did every thing in my power to deserve it. Her indelicacy surprises me?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Sure, Leontine, there's nothing so indelicate in being sensible of your merit. If so, I fear, I shall be the most guilty thing alive.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: But you mistake, my dear. The same attention I used to advance my merit with you, I practised to lessen it with her. What more could I do?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Let us now rather consider what's to be done. We have both dissembled too long‚ÄîI have always been ashamed‚ÄîI am now quite weary of it. Sure I could never have undergone so much for any other but you.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: And you shall find my gratitude equal to your kindest compliance. Tho' our friends should totally forsake us, Olivia, we can draw upon content for the deficiencies of fortune.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Then why should we defer our scheme of humble happiness, when it is now in our power? I may be the favourite of your father, it is true; but can it ever be thought, that his present kindness to a supposed child, will continue to a known deceiver?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: I have many reasons to believe it will. As his attachments are but few, they are lasting. His own marriage was a private one, as ours may be. Besides, I have sounded him already at a distance, and find all his answers exactly to our wish. Nay, by an expression or two that dropped from him, I am induced to think he knows of this affair.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Indeed! But that would be an happiness too great to be expected.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: However it be, I'm certain you have power over him; and am persuaded, if you informed him of our situation, that he would be disposed to pardon it.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: You had equal expectations, Leontine, from your last scheme with miss Richland, which you find has succeeded most wretchedly.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: And that's the best reason for trying another.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: If it must be so, I submit.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: As we could wish, he comes this way. Now, my dearest Olivia, be resolute. I'll just retire within hearing, to come in at a proper time, either to share your danger, or confirm your victory. [Exit.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Yes, I must forgive her; and yet not too easily, neither. It will be proper to keep up the decorums
of resentment a little, if it be only to impress her with an idea of my authority.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: How I tremble to approach him!‚ÄîMight I presume, sir‚ÄîIf I interrupt you‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: No, child, where I have an affection, it is not a little thing can interrupt me. Affection gets over little things.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Sir, you're too kind. I'm sensible how ill I deserve this partiality. Yet, heaven knows, there is nothing I would not do to gain it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And you have but too well succeeded, you little hussey, you. With those endearing ways of yours, on my conscience, I could be brought to forgive any thing, unless it were a very great offence indeed.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: But mine is such an offence‚ÄîWhen you know my guilt‚ÄîYes, you shall know it, tho' I feel the greatest pain in the confession.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Why then, if it be so very great a pain, you may spare yourself the trouble; for I know every syllable of the matter before you begin.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Indeed! Then I'm undone.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Ay, miss, you wanted to steal a match, without letting me know it, did you! But, I'm not worth being consulted, I suppose, when there's to be a marriage in my own family. No, I'm to have no hand in the disposal of my own children. No, I'm
nobody. I'm to be a mere article of family lumber; a piece of crack'd china to be stuck up in a corner.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Dear sir, nothing but the dread of your authority could induce us to conceal it from you.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: No, no, my consequence is no more; I'm as little minded as a dead Russian in winter, just stuck up with a pipe in his mouth till there comes a thaw‚ÄîIt goes to my heart to vex her.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: I was prepared, sir, for your anger, and despaired of pardon, even while I presumed to ask it. But your severity shall never abate my affection, as my punishment is but justice.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And yet you should not despair neither, Livy. We ought to hope all for the best.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: And do you permit me to hope, sir! Can I ever expect to be forgiven! But hope has too long deceived me.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Why then, child, it shan't deceive you now, for I forgive you this very moment. I forgive you all; and now you are indeed my daughter.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: O transport! This kindness overpowers me.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I was always against severity to our children. We have been young and giddy ourselves, and we can't expect boys and girls to be old before their time.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: What generosity! But can you forget the many falsehoods, the dissimulation‚Äî

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: You did indeed dissemble, you urchin you; but where's the girl that won't dissemble for an husband! My wife and I had never been married, if we had not dissembled a little beforehand.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: It shall be my future care never to put such generosity to a second trial. And as for the partner of my offence and folly, from his native honour, and the just sense he has of his duty, I can answer for him that‚Äî

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Permit him thus to answer for himself. (Kneeling.) Thus, sir, let me speak my gratitude for this unmerited forgiveness. Yes, sir, this even exceeds all your former tenderness: I now can boast the most indulgent of fathers. The life he gave, compared to this, was but a trifling blessing.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And, good sir, who sent for you, with that fine tragedy face, and flourishing manner? I don't know what we have to do with your gratitude upon this occasion.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: How, sir! Is it possible to be silent, when so much obliged! Would you refuse me the pleasure of being grateful! of adding my thanks to my Olivia's! of sharing in the transports that you have thus occasioned?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Lord, sir, we can be happy enough, without your coming in to make up the party. I don't know what's
the matter with the boy all this day; he has got into such a rhodomontade manner all this morning!

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: But, sir, I that have so large a part in the benefit, is it not my duty to shew my joy? Is the being admitted to your favour so slight an obligation? Is the happiness of marrying my Olivia so small a blessing?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Marrying Olivia! marrying Olivia! marrying his own sister! Sure the boy is out of his senses. His own sister!

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: My sister!

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Sister! How have I been mistaken! [Aside.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Some curs'd mistake in all this I find. [Aside.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: What does the booby mean, or has he any meaning. Eh, what do you mean, you blockhead you?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Mean, sir‚Äîwhy, sir‚Äîonly when my sister is to be married, that I have the pleasure of marrying her, sir that is, of giving her away, sir‚ÄîI have made a point of it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: O, is that all. Give her away. You have made a point of it. Then you had as good make a point of first giving away yourself, as I'm going to prepare the writings between you and miss Richland this very minute. What a fuss is here about nothing! Why, what's the matter now? I thought I had made you at least as happy as you could wish.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: O! yes, sir, very happy.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Do you foresee any thing, child? You look as if you did. I think if any thing was to be foreseen, I have as sharp a look out as another: and yet I foresee nothing. [Exit.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: What can it mean?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: He knows something, and yet for my life I can't tell what.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: It can't be the connexion between us, I'm pretty certain.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Whatever it be, my dearest, I'm resolv'd to put it out of fortune's power to repeat our mortification. I'll haste, and prepare for our journey to Scotland this very evening. My friend Honeywood has promis'd me his advice and assistance. I'll go to him, and repose our distresses on his friendly bosom: and I know so much of his honest heart, that if he can't relieve our uneasinesses, he will at least share them. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE, YOUNG HONEYWOOD'S house.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: LOOKY, sir, I have arrested as good men as you in my time: no disparagement of you neither. Men that would go forty guineas on a game of cribbage. I challenge the town to shew a man in more genteeler practice than myself.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Without all question, Mr.‚Äî. I forget your name, sir?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: How can you forget what you never knew? he, he, he.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: May I beg leave to ask your name?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Then, pray, sir, what is your name, sir?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: That I didn't promise to tell you. He, he, he. A joke breaks no bones, as we say among us that practice the law.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: You may have reason for keeping it a secret perhaps?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: The law does nothing without reason. I'm asham'd to tell my name to no man, sir. If you can shew cause, as why, upon a special capus, that I should prove my name‚ÄîBut, come, Timothy Twitch is my name. And, now you know my name, what have you to say to that?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Nothing in the world, good Mr. Twitch, but that I have a favour to ask, that's all.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Ay, favours are more easily asked than granted, as we say among us that practice the law. I have taken an oath against granting favours. Would you have me perjure myself?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: But my request will come recommended in so strong a manner, as, I believe, you'll have no scruple (pulling out his purse) The thing is only this: I believe I shall be able to discharge this trifle in two or three days at farthest; but as I would not have the affair known for the world, I have thoughts of keeping you, and your good friend here, about me till the debt is discharged; for which, I shall be properly grateful.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Oh! that's another maxum, and altogether within my oath. For certain, if an honest man is to get any thing by a thing, there's no reason why all things should not be done in civility.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Doubtless, all trades must live, Mr. Twitch; and yours is a necessary one. (Gives him money)

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Oh! your honour; I hope your honour takes nothing amiss as I does, as I does nothing but my duty in so doing. I'm sure no man can say I ever give a gentleman, that was a gentleman, ill usage. If I saw that a gentleman was a gentleman, I have taken money not to see him for ten weeks together.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Tenderness is a virtue, Mr. Twitch.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Ay, sir, it's a perfect treasure. I love to see a gentleman with a tender heart. I don't know, but I think I have a tender heart myself. If all that I have lost by my heart was put together, it would make a‚Äîbut no matter for that.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Don't account it lost, Mr. Twitch. The ingratitude of the world can never deprive us of the conscious happiness of having acted with humanity ourselves.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Humanity, sir, is a jewel. It's better than gold. I love humanity. People may say, that we, in our way, have no humanity; but I'll shew you my humanity this moment. There's my follower here, little Flanigan, with a wife and four children, a guinea or two would be more to him, than twice as much to another. Now, as I can't shew him any humanity myself, I must beg leave you'll do it for me.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I assure you, Mr. Twitch, yours is a most powerful recommendation. (giving money to the follower)

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p:
Sir, you're a gentleman. I see you know what to do with your money. But, to business: we are to be
with you here as your friends, I suppose. But set in case company comes.‚ÄîLittle Flanigan here, to be sure, has a good face; a very good face: but then, he is a little seedy, as we say among us that practise the law. Not well in cloaths. Smoke the pocketholes.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, that shall be remedied without delay.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, miss Richland is below.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: How unlucky! Detain her a moment. We must improve my good friend, little Mr. Flanigan's appearance first. Here, let Mr. Flanigan have a suit of my cloaths‚Äîquick‚Äîthe brown and silver‚ÄîDo you hear?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: That your honour gave away to the begging gentleman that makes verses, because it was as good as new.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: The white and gold then.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: That, your honour, I made bold to sell, because it was good for nothing.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, the first that comes to hand then. The blue and gold then. I believe Mr. Flanigan will look best in blue. [Exit Flanigan.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p:
Rabbit me, but little Flanigan will look well in any thing. Ah, if your honour knew that bit of flesh as well as I do, you'd be perfectly in love with him.
There's not a prettier scout in the four counties after a shy-cock than he: scents like a hound; sticks like a weazle. He was master of the ceremonies to the black queen of Morocco, when I took him to follow me. (Re-enter Flanigan.) Heh, ecod, I think he looks so well, that I don't care if I have a suit from the same place for myself.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, well, I hear the lady coming. Dear Mr. Twitch, I beg you'll give your friend directions not to speak. As for yourself, I know you will say nothing without being directed.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Never you fear me; I'll shew the lady that I have something to say for myself as well as another. One man has one way of talking, and another man has another, that's all the difference between them.

div3.stage: Enter MISS RICHLAND and her MAID.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: You'll be surprised, sir, with this visit. But you know I'm yet to thank you for chusing my little library.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Thanks, madam, are unnecessary; as it was I that was obliged by your commands. Chairs here. Two of my very good friends, Mr. Twitch and Mr. Flanigan. Pray, gentlemen, sit without ceremony.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Who can these odd-looking men be! I fear it is as I was informed. It must be so. (Aside.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF
sp.p: Pretty weather, very pretty weather for the time of the year, madam.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Very good circuit weather in the country.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: You officers are generally favourites among the ladies. My friends, madam, have been upon very disagreeable duty, I assure you. The fair should, in some measure, recompence the toils of the brave!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Our officers do indeed deserve every favour. The gentlemen are in the marine service, I presume, sir?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Why, madam, they do‚Äîoccasionally serve in the fleet, madam. A dangerous service!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I'm told so. And I own, it has often surprised me, that, while we have had so many instances of bravery there, we have had so few of wit at home to praise it.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I grant, madam, that our poets have not written as our soldiers have fought; but they have done all they could, and Hawke or Amherst could do no more.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I'm quite displeased when I see a fine subject spoiled by a dull writer.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: We should not be so severe against dull writers, madam. It is ten to one, but the dullest writer exceeds the most rigid French critic who presumes to despise him.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Damn the French, the parle vous, and all that belongs to them.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! honest Mr. Flanigan. A true English officer, madam; he's not contented with beating the French, but he will scold them too.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Yet, Mr. Honeywood, this does not convince me but that severity in criticism is necessary. It was our first adopting the severity of French taste, that has brought them in turn to taste us.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Taste us! By the Lord, madam, they devour us. Give monseers but a taste, and I'll be damn'd but they come in for a bellyful.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Very extraordinary this.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: But very true. What makes the bread rising? the parle vous that devour us. What makes the mutton fivepence a pound? the parle vous that eat it up. What makes the beer threepence-halfpenny a pot?‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ah! the vulgar rogues; all will be out. (Aside.) Right, gentlemen, very right, upon my word, and quite to the purpose. They draw a parallel, madam, between the mental taste and that of our senses. We are injured as much by French severity in the one, as by French rapacity in the other. That's their meaning.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Tho' I don't see the force of the parallel, yet, I'll own, that we should sometimes pardon books, as we do our friends, that have now and then agreeable abfurdities to recommend them.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: That's all my eye. The king only can pardon, as the law says: for, set in case‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I'm quite of your opinion, sir. I see the whole drift of your argument. Yes, certainly, our presuming to pardon any work, is arrogating a power that belongs to another. If all have power to condemn, what writer can be free?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: By his habus corpus. His habus corpus can set him free at any time: for, set in case‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I'm obliged to you, sir, for the hint. If, madam, as my friend observes, our laws are so careful of a gentleman's person, sure we ought to be equally careful of his dearer part, his fame.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Ay, but if so be a man's nabb'd, you know‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Mr. Flanigan, if you spoke for ever, you could not improve the last observation. For my own part, I think it conclusive.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: As for the matter of that, mayhap‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Nay, sir, give me leave in this instance to be positive. For, where is the necessity of censuring works without genius, which must shortly sink of themselves? what is it, but aiming our unnecessary blow against a victim already under the hands of justice?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Justice! O, by the elevens, if you talk about justice, I think I am at home there: for, in a course of law‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Twitch, I discern what you'd be at perfectly; and I believe the lady must be sensible of the art with which it is introduced. I suppose you perceive the meaning, madam, of his course of law.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I protest, sir, I do not. I perceive only that you answer one gentleman before he has finished, and the other before he has well begun.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Madam, you are a gentlewoman, and I will make the matter out. This here question is about severity and justice, and pardon, and the like of they. Now to explain the thing‚Äî

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: O! curse your explanations. [Aside.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Leontine, sir, below, desires to speak with you upon earnest business.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: That's lucky. (Aside.) Dear madam, you'll excuse me and my good friends here, for a few minutes. There are books, madam, to amuse you. Come, gentlemen, you know I make no ceremony with such friends. After you, sir. Excuse me. Well, if I must. But I know your natural politeness.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Before and behind, you know.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Ay, ay, before and behind, before and behind. [Exeunt Honeywood, Bailiff, and Follower.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: What can all this mean, Garnet?

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Mean, madam? why, what should it mean, but what Mr. Lofty sent you here to see? These people he calls officers are officers sure enough: sheriff's officers; bailiffs, madam.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Ay, it is certainly so. Well, tho' his perplexities are far from giving me pleasure, yet I own there's something very ridiculous in them, and a just punishment for his dissimulation.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: And so they are. But I wonder, madam, that the lawyer you just employed to pay his debts, and set him free, has not done it by this time. He ought at least to have been here before now. But lawyers are always more ready to get a man into troubles, than out of them.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: For miss Richland to undertake setting him free, I own, was quite unexpected. It has totally unhinged my schemes to reclaim him. Yet, it gives me pleasure to find, that, among a number of worthless friendships, he has made one acquisition of real value; for there must be some softer passion on her side that prompts this generosity. Ha! here before me: I'll endeavour to sound her affections. Madam, as I am the person that have had some demands upon the gentleman of this house, I hope you'll excuse me, if, before I enlarged him, I wanted to see yourself.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: The precaution was very unnecessary, sir. I suppose your wants were only such as my agent had power to satisfy.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Partly, madam. But, I was also willing you should be fully apprized of the character of the gentleman you intended to serve.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: It must come, sir, with a very ill grace from you. To censure it, after what you have done, would look like malice; and, to speak favourably of a character you have oppressed, would be impeaching your own. And sure, his tenderness, his humanity, his universal friendship, may atone for many faults.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: That friendship, madam, which is exerted in too wide a sphere, becomes totally useless. Our bounty, like a drop of water, disappears when diffused too widely. They, who pretend most to this universal benevolence, are either deceivers, or dupes. Men who desire to cover their private ill-nature, by a pretended regard for all; or, men who, reasoning themselves into false feelings, are more earnest in pursuit of splendid, than of useful virtues.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I am surprised, sir, to hear one, who has probably been a gainer by the folly of others, so severe in his censure of it.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Whatever I may have gained by folly, madam, you see I am willing to prevent your losing by it.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Your cares for me, sir, are unnecessary. I always suspect those services which are denied where they are wanted, and offered, perhaps, in hopes of a refusal. No, sir, my directions have been given, and I insist upon their being complied with.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Thou amiable woman! I can no longer contain the expressions of my gratitude: my pleasure. You see before you one, who has been equally careful of his interest; one, who has for some time been a concealed spectator of his follies, and only punished, in hopes to reclaim them‚Äîhis uncle!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir William Honeywood! You amaze me. How shall I conceal my confusion? I fear, sir, you'll think I have been too forward in my services. I confess I‚Äî

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Don't make any apologies, madam. I only find myself unable to repay the obligation. And yet, I have been trying my interest of late to serve you. Having learnt, madam, that you had some demands upon government, I have, tho' unasked, been your solicitor there.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir, I'm infinitely obliged to your intentions. But my guardian has employed another gentleman who assures him of success.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Who, the important little man that visits here? Trust me, madam, he's quite contemptible among men in power, and utterly unable to serve you. Mr. Lofty's promises are much better known to people of fashion, than his person, I assure you.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: How have we been deceived! As sure as can be, here he comes.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Does he! Remember I'm to continue unknown. My return to England has not as yet been made public. With what impudence he enters!

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Let the chariot‚Äîlet my chariot drive off; I'll visit to his grace's in a chair. Miss Richland here before me! Punctual, as usual, to the calls of humanity. I'm very sorry, madam, things of this kind should happen, especially to a man I have shewn every where, and carried amongst us as a particular acquaintance.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I find, sir, you have the art of making the misfortunes of others your own.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: My dear madam, what can a private man like me do? One man can't do every thing; and then, I do so much in this way every day: let me see; something considerable might be done for him by subscription; it could not fail if I carried the list. I'll undertake to set down a brace of dukes, two dozen lords, and half the lower house, at my own peril.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: And, after all, it's more than probable, sir, he might reject the offer of such powerful patronage.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Then, madam, what can we do? You know I never make promises. In truth, I once or twice tried to do something with him in the way of business; but, as I often told his uncle, sir William Honeywood, the man was utterly impracticable.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: His uncle! Then that gentleman, I suppose, is a particular friend of your.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Meaning me, sir?‚ÄîYes, madam, as I often said, my dear sir William, you are sensible I would do any thing, as far as my poor interest goes, to serve your family: but what can be done; there's no procuring first-rate places for ninth-rate abilities.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I have heard of sir William Honeywood; he's abroad in employment: he confided in your judgment, I suppose.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Why, yes, madam, I believe sir William had some reason to confide in my judgment; one little reason, perhaps.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Pray, sir, what was it?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Why, madam‚Äîbut let it go no further‚Äîit was I procured him his place.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Did you, sir?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Either you or I, sir.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: This, Mr. Lofty, was very kind indeed.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: I did love him, to be sure; he had some amusing qualities; no man was fitter to be toast-master to a club, or had a better head.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: A better head?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Ay, at a bottle. To be sure, he was as dull as a choice spirit: but hang it, he was grateful, very grateful; and gratitude hides a multitude of faults.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: He might have reason, perhaps. His place is pretty considerable, I'm told.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: A trifle, a mere trifle, among us men of business. The truth is, he wanted dignity to fill up a greater.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Dignity of person, do you mean, sir? I'm told he's much about my size and figure, sir.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Ay, tall enough for a marching regiment; but then he wanted a something‚Äîa consequence of form‚Äîa kind of a‚ÄîI believe the lady perceives my meaning.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: O, perfectly: you courtiers can do any thing, I see.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: My dear madam, all this is but a meer exchange: we do greater things for one another every day. Why, as thus, now: let me suppose you the first lord of the treasury; you have an employment in you that I want; I have a place in me that you want; do me here, do you there: interest of both sides, few words, flat, done and done, and its over.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: A thought strikes me. (Aside.) Now you mention sir William Honeywood, madam; and as he seems, sir, an acquaintance of yours; you'll be glad to hear he's arrived from Italy; I had it from a friend who knows him as well as he does me, and you may depend on my information.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: The devil he is! If I had known that, we should not have been quite so well acquainted. [Aside.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: He is certainly returned; and, as this gentleman is a friend of yours, he can be of signal service to us, by introducing me to him; there are some papers relative to your affairs, that require dispatch and his inspection.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: This gentleman, Mr. Lofty, is a person employed in my affairs: I know you'll serve us.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: My dear madam, I live but to serve you. Sir William shall even wait upon him, if you think proper to command it.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: That would be quite unnecessary.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Well, we must introduce you then. Call upon me‚Äîlet me see‚Äîay, in two days.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Now, or the opportunity will be lost for ever.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Well, if it must be now, now let it be. But damn it, that's unfortunate; my lord Grig's cursed Pensacola business comes on this very hour, and I'm engaged to attend‚Äîanother time‚Äî

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: A short letter to sir William will do.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: You shall have it; yet, in my opinion, a letter is a very bad way of going to work; face to face, that's my way.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: The letter, sir, will do quite as well.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Zounds! sir, do you pretend to direct me; direct me in the business of office? Do you know me, sir? who am I?

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Lofty, this request is not so much his as mine; if my commands‚Äîbut you despise my power.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Delicate creature! your commands could even controul a debate at midnight: to a power so constitutional, I am all obedience and tranquillity. He shall have a letter; where is my secretary? Dubardieu! And yet, I protest I don't like this way of doing business I think if I spoke first to sir William‚ÄîBut you will have it so. [Exit with Miss Richland.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! This too is one of my nephew's hopeful associates. O vanity, thou constant deceiver, how do all thy efforts to exalt, serve but to sink us! Thy false colourings, like those employed to heighten beauty, only seem to mend that bloom which they contribute to destroy.
